# Overview 
This is the analysis of white matter dsi studio connectometry for Maze and Loop 

# <span style="color: darkblue;">Methods </span> 
##### **Participants** 
* Total number of scans = 120 (males and females )
  * Total scans used in analysis= 118 
  *Exclude subs 329 and 372 from analyses
        
##### **Scan parameters** 
* Locations from UCSB and UCI

##### **Exclusions** 
* 347 was excluded due to low quality outliar

##### **QSIprep** 
* Version used: 0.16.0RC3
* The following parameters were used
  * dwi_denoise_window **5** 
  * hmc_model **3dSHORE** 
  * hmc-transform **Rigid** 
  * shoreline_iters **2**

### **DSI Studio**
*Version and tags used 
  * chen-2022-07-31

##### **Correlational connectometry**

###### **Parameters for all** 
* T-threshold = 2.5
* Length = 25
* Permutation = 4,000
* pruning 4
* non normalized QA

#### **Analyses** 
* All subjects
* Men
* Women
* Stage
  * Pre
  * Peri 
  * Post

##### Maze {.tabset} 
###### Accuracy 
###### Path Effieciency 

##### Loop {.tabset} 
######  Position Error Rad 3
######  Position Error Average
######  Degree Error Rad 3
######  Degree Error Average
######  Angular Error Rad 3
######  Angular Error Average

<!---------------------------------------QA Accuracy--------------------------------->



<!---------------------------------------Results---------------------------------  -->

# <span style="color: darkorange;"> Maze Accuracy </span>  {.tabset .tabset-dropdown}
## QA {.tabset}
### Summary of results 
There were both positive and negative correlations between QA and maze performance when all subjects were included in the analysis. When men were analyzed separately, men men displayed more negatively associated correlations between QA and maze performance. Women displayed tracts with predominantly positive correlations between QA and performance. When split by menopause stagge, Pre and post displayed both positive and negative correlations while peri displayed only positive correlations with performance. 

### All subjects
```{r QA all subjects correlations,echo=FALSE, results='hide',message=FALSE}
# write something to read in the csv file and extract the stats and place them all together 
# make sure CSVs do not have a header
working_dir <- "/Users/danielacossio/Library/CloudStorage/GoogleDrive-dcossio1@uci.edu/My Drive/White matter tract/MidlifeWM_DSI2023/DSI/maze/Accuracy/QA" 
setwd(working_dir)

rows2grab <- c("Tract Name", "number of tracts","mean length(mm)","diameter(mm)", "volume(mm^3)")

QA_acc_all_pos <- read.csv('allSubs/QA_all_pos.csv', header=FALSE) %>%  filter(V1 %in% rows2grab) %>% t() %>% `colnames<-`(rows2grab) %>% `[`(-c(1),) %>% as.data.frame()

QA_acc_all_neg <- read.csv('allSubs/QA_all_neg.csv', header=FALSE) %>%  filter(V1 %in% rows2grab) %>% t() %>% `colnames<-`(rows2grab) %>% `[`(-c(1),) %>% as.data.frame()

```
#### <span style="color: hotpink;"> Positive ( FDR= 0.043228) </span> 
```{r, layout="l-body-outset",echo=FALSE}
knitr::kable(QA_acc_all_pos, row.names=F)
```
####  <span class="text-center" style="color: Teal;"> Neg ( FDR= 0.122807)</span> 
```{r, echo=FALSE}
knitr::kable(QA_acc_all_neg, row.names=F)
```
